title: theory of art is Susanne Langer’s Feeling and Form

An introduction to theories of expression can be found in Chapter 7 of Monroe Beardsley’s Aesthetics: Problems in the Philosophy of Criticism
Nelson Goodman advances a view of expression as metaphorical exemplification in Chapter 2 of his Languages of Art

title: For criticism of the view that expression is metaphorical exemplification, see: Guy Sircello, Mind and Art: An Essay on the Varieties of Expression

also contains a major discussion of artistic expression. There are many articles on expression in the philosophical literature. Good places to start reading are: Robert Stecker, “Expression of Emotion in (Some of) the Arts

title: One much-debated issue concerning aesthetic properties that is not discussed in this chapter concerns whether or not aesthetic concepts are condition-governed. For an introduction to this topic, see: Frank Sibley, “Aesthetic Concepts

Peter Kivy has used the narrative approach to explain the enfranchisement of absolute music as art in his Philosophies of Arts
Chapter 1. The notion of art as a conversation in the section on identifying narratives in this chapter of the present book is adapted from Jeffrey Wieand, “Putting Forward A Work of Art

There are a number of contemporary approaches to the problems discussed in this chapter that, given considerations of space, have not been reviewed in this book. Some notable ones include: Arthur Danto, The Transfiguration of the Commonplace
For a recent anthology of new work on defining and identifying art, see Theories of Art
